fields.physical_description:
South German marquetry chest with Charity and Justice
Probably missing stand that would have enclosed bottom half inch or so of exposed base.

The oak carcase dovetailed (one large plank at front and back, the back with 5 large dovetails (with visible scribe lines) holding the chest ends in place), on which marquetry panels and mouldings are applied. The bottom of 3 planks without any evidence of cut-down feet (to be confirmed). The back formed of three planks glued. 
The lid held on two original tinned iron strap hinges fixed with round-headed rivets, and panelled, containing two panels of pine or ash (with visible shrinkage across the grain) - with modern fillets to hold them in place, surrounded by small panels with geometric ornament, all with mitred border fillets of a dark wood (rosewood?) inside and out(?). The front and end edges of the lid with an external moulding held with square pegs, and end cleats. Most of the lid veneers seem to have been long missing. 
The ends with central strapwork panel within simple mitred fillets (of a dark wood) forming a simple geometric design, and with wrought iron handles set over two diamond-shaped plates.

The marquetry front with three arched panels set between pilasters (with vertebrate foliage over a baldachino) over a rusticated ground with sprouting weeds. The central panel of grotesque ornament (with spandrels containing parrots) surmounted by strapwork, and flanked by two panels with Justice (left) after Goltzius, and Charity (right), both with surrounding small panels with hunting scenes or grotesques. (The two larger panels above Justice and Charity each with a double-headed eagle bearing an armorial(?) shield.) Below the three main panels a series of 9 smaller panels with hunt scenes, foliage or male figures standing amid foliage. The marquetry of 5 or 6(?) colours including green stain.



The interior surfaces are neatly planed. With a till (PR) with lid (with moulded edge) and decorative skirt all in good condition (note wear from till lid against chest lid (as shown in illustrations) where lid was used as lid prop). 

Metalwork
Two original tinned iron hinges with spear tips matching the hasp plate. The original large internal lock now missing (but ornate escutcheon and nails remain), and the hasp male now missing from its surviving plate nailed to the underside of the lid. A later (18c or 19c) lock and hasp fitted and keyhole added.

Finish
Discoloured varnish overall.
fields.dimensions: Height: 64 cm, Width: 183 cm, Depth: 72 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Oak carcase with marquetry of different woods
fields.history_note:
Bequeathed by John Russell. (MA/1/R2117)
Condition in 1914 described as "damaged, many portions of decoration missing"..."the front with fine [five?] marquetry designs in which are represented the Virgin & Child and Justice  under round arches, with panels containing sprays of flowers and birds".

MS note received in Museum 19/2/1914 from Miss Russell (?):
It is believed to have been in the family since the beginning of the 17th century when Robert Russell yeoman was living at Southfields, Sevenoaks. The genealogy before 1600 is not quite proven but the following appears likely to be the history of the chest.
Will of Nicholas Russell 1568

1stt? Elizabeth his wife his house & garden at Lamberhurst Sussex during her widowhood if she marry again his son John to have the same to his heirs for ever....? his mother
10/ yearly 6/8 yearly to his brother William 
if John dies without heir(?) I give the same to my son Robert & his heirs for ever.
if the said William dies before John then the said John 
shall pay to the said Robert 40/-
My great chest shall always remain to the house.
To William and Robert my sons & Margaret and Faith my daughter 20/- each to be paid
them by Eliz my wife at the age of 21 a...?
The rest of my goods to my said wife when I ...

William Foale John St.. to be ....

In 1648 Baptism at Sevenoaks of 
Robert son of Robert Russell
also in 1672 the Burial of John son of Robert Russell  (probably a connection.....?

Contemporary Russells: John Russell of Cobham 1530
Nicholas Russell of Lamberhurst 1568
William Russell of Dartford 1552
George Russell ? of above of Gravesend

Robert Russell of Sevenoaks
Robert Russell d.1682 Sevenoaks (Shoreham?)
Robert Russell d.1648 [Horton Ruby?]The Court Lodge
Robert Russell d.1681 [Horton Ruby?]
Robert Russell d.1713 [Horton Ruby?]
James b1783 [Horton Ruby?]
John b.1824 [Horton Ruby?] the court lodge
died at St Johns Sutton at Home 1911 age 87 1/2
fields.historical_context_note:
Apparently good provenance. Rare, unrestored condition. Dirt and (perhaps discoloured shellac) might help suggest original colour scheme more vividly.
Convincing example of late 16c work. A challenge to show in gallery (even if a new stand suggested the original (now missing), because the lid has so many losses, but it could be shown with the lid raised to obviate this, and show the plain interior and underside of lid. The front needs careful lighting and visibility (eg raised high) to make it interesting. Must not be conserved without very careful discussion.
